titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. Monday.

Convalescent; but not well enough to mount my horse— The day continued showery, with distant thunder and lightening; and damp with sultry heat— A young man named Bryan, came to solicit a subscription for an Apprentice’s library in the City. After dinner I rode with Mrs Adams in the Carriage to the Post Office, where I found a Letter from Commodore Chauncey— The Season of the year has come when I cannot write in the Evening, and the Season of life has come when I can scarcely hold a pen— I wasted great part of the day upon my observations on parties, yet wrote very little— I have abandoned all thought of other composition. This Evening I read the first Book of Washington Irving’s life of Columbus, with which I am well pleased. It gives the early years of the link between the History of the old world, and of the new—is scanty of facts, and somewhat incredible as to the manner of his arriving in Portugal—but the narrative is entertaining traces with sagacity and judgment the sources of the discovery in the great navigator’s mind.
2. V:30. Tuesday.

I resumed this morning the practice of riding on horseback, and called upon Mr Samuel Harrison Smith. I mentioned that in M. Carey’s Olive-Branch there were extracts from publications under the signature of Pelham in Hudson and Goodwin’s Connecticut Courant at Hartford in 1796. and republished at Philadelphia, in a paper called the New-World, by S. H. Smith. I asked him if he was the person, and if he was, whether he had a file of the paper that contained those Essays, and could lend it to me— He said he was the publisher of the paper, and believed he had an incomplete file of it, which he would look up and send me. It was an experiment he had made just after he was of age, and which did not succeed. It was a paper published twice a day— A Quarto Sheet in the Morning, and a Newspaper in the Evening. But he could not keep it up more than one year— We had some further Conversation upon the Politics of those Times and the Revolutions of opinion since.— My parley with Mr. Smith shortened my ride— Dr Huntt was here after breakfast, and prescribed a regimen for me, for some time— Mr Clarke the late Treasurer came to take leave; being upon his return to Pennsylvania, he has been remove from Office, and one Campbell, a member of the Council in Virginia appointed in his place— Mr Frye and Mr Smith were here after dinner. Mr Frye says it is reported there is a delinquency of 8 or 10,000 dollars in the accounts of the late Register of the Treasury Joseph Nourse.
3. V:30. Wednesday.

Rode this Morning To the Potowmack Bridge and Capitol— Renounced the idea of finishing my remarks on Parties, and doubt whether they ever will be finished— Commenced my preparations for departure— Wrote Letters to my Son Charles, to George Sullivan, and to W. H. Jones, at Boston— Made out an Account of monies paid by me to be delivered to Mr Frye, Guardian to T. J. Hellen. This Account has been running into disorder these four years, and my time has been so absorbed with public business that I have been utterly unable to give due attention to my private concerns— Mr Frye sent me four Accounts settled by T. Cook the former Guardian of T. J. Hellen, at the Orphans Court; with the help of which, and of an account made out last September by my Son George, and a copy of Dr Abbott’s Account with T. J. Hellen, I made out a Statement of Account, with the exception of payments made to me by Mr Frye, and I rode to his house with John after dinner, and asked him for a minute of them which he gave me— I also commenced Memoranda to leave with my Son John.
4. V. Thursday.

Rode my horse to the Potowmack, and bathed in the river— Swam about ten minutes, and returned home to Breakfast. Had a morning visit from two of the Sons of Judge Thruston, who lost their way, coming from their father’s Residence on the Hills back of Georgetown, to the City— Thomas, the one who has been dismissed from the department of State, says he is glad of it, and that if the place were offered him again he would not accept it. I continued occupied in preparation for departure with the assortment of papers the whole day— I look up those only that I must take with me— It would take a Month at least to arrange them all. I finished the Statement of Account of expenses for T. J. Hellen paid by me— Rode after dinner with John to Mr Frye’s; and he not being at home I left the Account and papers with Mrs Frye.
5. V:30. Friday.

Rode to the Potowmack. Bathed and swam short of 15 minutes in the River— Returned by the way of the Capitol Hill; called at Judge Cranch’s, but he was at his Office at the City-Hall— I saw his son William, and informed him of our intention to leave the City next Monday, to return to Quincy; and that we would take any Letters for the family, that the judge might wish to send— Back to Breakfast at 8. Dr Todsen paid me a morning visit to take leave— He says he is going into Pennsylvania to attempt the practice of his profession. That he has been flattered with hope by promises of employment under this administration, but has no prospect of obtaining it, and will give up the pursuit. Mr Daniel Brent and Mr Walsh were here after dinner— Walsh was as courteous with me as ever— He urged me very earnestly to set about writing Memoirs of my father’s life; and also of my own times. I told him I had had it in contemplation, and still intended it; but that I found cotemporary history could not be published with truth and safety— That the Collisions in my father’s life, with Mr Jefferson, and with General Hamilton, would require great boldness of narrative; and perhaps I should be obliged like Horace Walpole to seal up my Manuscript, and direct that it should be published not till 30 years after my death— Walsh told me that he had always thought Hamilton, in his conduct towards my father entirely wrong—and that he differed in that from Hopkinson— He said, too, that upon a rumour that he was going to write a History of my father’s Administration, Coll. Troup of New-York had written to him earnestly soliciting him to say nothing against Hamilton— Mr Walsh compared the proceedings in the British Parliament with those in our Congress, and thought there was more Independence, and more free exercise of mind in Parliament than in Congress—in which I differed from him— There is perhaps as much. We conversed freely upon other topics of general politics upwards of an hour; which abridged my subsequent ride with my Son John.
6. VI. Saturday.

I rode to the Potowmack, bathed and swam a quarter of an hour against the Tide. I think my health has suffered, by omission of my usual Summer bathing and swimming till so late in the Season— I was engaged the whole day again in preparing for departure but our plan is now changed. My wife has determined, to remain here with John’s wife and our infant grand daughter, and my Son John is to go with me to Quincy, to return here about the middle of July; and I propose to return in October. This will delay for a day or two more my departure.
Mr Munroe the late Postmaster paid me a long morning visit— He told me he had a Letter from his eldest Son, Thomas informing him that he had been promoted to be Aid de Camp to the Grand Duke Constantine, with the rank of Colonel, and an increase of pay, so that he would henceforth be enabled to support himself— Mr Monroe told me also various circumstances respecting his own removal, and the present state of Affairs in the Cabinet— The Scandalous Chronicle like every thing else cowers before the idol of popularity— It dares not speak out but it whispers— The day was showery— After dinner I walked with my wife my Son John, and his wife to the Columbian Mills— The Ladies returned in the Carriage— John and I walked.
7. V:30. Sunday—

I rode to the Presbyterian Church and heard Mr Campbell, from Philippians 2:8. [“]And being found in fashion as a man, he humbled himself, and became obedient unto death, even the death of the Cross.” It was communion day and the Sermon was occasional— The communion service was performed; partly by Mr Campbell, and partly by Dr Laurie who came in after it had commenced— There is more solemnity in the Presbyterian manner of administering the communion than in that of any other that I have witnessed— As I was walking home from Church I met Mr. Thomas Law, who had called to take leave of me— He said he expected to sail in about three weeks for England— He thought he should never return to this Country. He leaves his Son Edmund here, in very ill health— I overtook also two persons walking who spoke to me— One said his name was Marsh; the other Adams, both from the interior of New-York. They had been at Church, and walked on the way I was coming, I believe only for the sake of speaking to me. Mr and Mrs Frye with their Son Thomas and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us. Mr Harrison the first Auditor, Mr Ringgold the Marshal, and Dr Huntt came in while we were at dinner, and spent perhaps two hours with us.— We heard of the explosion of the Steam Frigate Fulton, at Brooklyn Navy-Yard, New-York Thursday last; with loss of more than thirty lives, and as many wounded— The Calamities of others repeat the admonitions of my own— I continue reading the Life of Columbus, and on reading this Evening the narrative of the conduct of Martin Alonzo Pinzon, on the first voyage, and before, the very important and essential part performed by him in fitting out the expedition, the dangers he encountered, and the services which he rendered in the execution of it, the glory that he might have shared and the disgrace that he did incur, his mortification, contrasted with the triumph of Columbus both arriving on the same day at Palos—his remorse and speedy death, leaving a dishonoured name while that of Columbus brightens from age to age; led me into a train of meditations upon human Nature— How many Pinzon’s there are of the human species in all ages—and how few Columbuses in any Age.
8. V:15. Monday.

Rode the ten mile round before Breakfast— Met Mr Van-Buren riding also his horse, and we stop’d and exchanged salutations— Van Buren is now Secretary of State— He is the manager, by whom the present Administration has been brought into power. He has played over again the game of
Aaron Burr in 1800 with the addition of political inconsistency, in transferring his Allegiance from Crawford to Jackson— He sold the State of New-York to them both— His first bargain failed, by the turn of the choice of Electors in the Legislature. The second was barely accomplished, by the system of party management established in that State, and Van Buren is now enjoying his reward— His pale and haggard looks shew that it is already a reward of mortification— If it should prove as there is every probability that it will, a reward of treachery, it will be but his desert— Divine retribution is often accomplished by the perfidy of man— Nec lex est justior ulla. I was again occupied the whole day in the arrangement and assortment of papers, and preparing for departure— Yet I shall leave them in great disorder— Mr Rebello the Chargé d’Affaires from Brazil called here after dinner— Heavy thunder-gust.
9. V. Tuesday.

Morning ride to the Navy Yard and Eastern Branch Bridge. Captain Reed of the Navy paid me a morning visit; and after dinner Mr Harris of Louisa County Virginia, called with his Son, a youth of 15 whom he is going to place at West Point, and a Dr Porter— Mr Harris said that his friend Governor Barbour had given his son his admission for West Point. Before Evening we rode in the Carriage into the City, and viewed a house that my Son is building, and which is nearly finished— I was still occupied in the arrangement of my Books and Papers— I leave nine Chests numbered from 7 to 15. and seven Trunks, containing my Manuscript Letter Books and Diaries, and part of my papers— I have marked and numbered the keys which I leave in the Tiller of Chest N. 7. a second key of which I leave with Mrs Adams— I have commenced an inventory of small effects, which I must have more leisure to complete.
10. V. Wednesday.

There was rain this morning before Breakfast, and I postponed my ride on horseback till 2 in the afternoon when I went by the Race-ground and Pearce’s Mills to Adlum’s corner, and back through Georgetown. Continued the packing of my Trunks and Chests, and made some additions to the commencement of an inventory.— Short ride after dinner with John—we met Mr Frye returning from a call at our house— My wife was much affected at the prospect of our departure, and I myself was more so than perhaps was proper— I struggle to bring all my Sentiments within the pale of humble resignation, to the will of God, and implore his mercy to direct my path— My attention to my own concerns is not yet sufficiently awakened and now at the close of life it seems as if I were about to commence the world again— I answered this day two Letters— One from a person at New York by the name of John Adams; a native of Delft in Holland, but more than 20 years a resident in New-York, who gives me his genealogy and history, and proposes to give my name to his Son— The other was from Mr Southard. I received also a Letter form Daniel Goodenow of Alfred Maine, with a Copy of a Resolution of Citizens of York County in that State in honour of the late Administration—which I propose to answer from Quincy.
11— IV:30. Thursday. Washington to Baltimore.

At 8 O’Clock this Morning I left Meridian Hill, with my Son John, and a Mulatto man named John Porter, to return and resume my abode at Quincy— We left my wife, with my Son’s wife and infant daughter at Meridian Hill—intending to return to them— My Son in a month or six weeks; myself perhaps next October— The parting from my wife was distressing to her and to me— The Afflictions with which we have been visited especially the last have so weakened us in body and mind that our dejection of Spirit seems irrecoverable— We parted with anguish that I cannot describe. We went to the Stage-Office in our Carriage, and took the 9 O’Clock Stage for Baltimore. It was 25 minutes past nine when we started— We had two Ladies and one man as fellow passengers.— We dined at Merrill’s, and arrived at Barnum’s Hotel, Baltimore about half past four in the afternoon. We met at Merrill’s Dr Collins coming in his own Carriage from the City. We passed by the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway about 7 miles before reaching Baltimore— A deep cut of more than 70 feet— Met Mr John Barney at Barnum’s door. Several visitors called. R. H. Lee H. Niles— E. J. Coale, David Hoffman, Mr Newman, Luke Tiernan, Genl. Leakin, Mr Riston, Isaac Munro John Barney, and others. I wrote to my wife, and then went and passed the latter part of the Evening at E. J. Coales’s— Mr Smith performed on the musical glasses invented by his Grandfather judge Francis Hopkinson, and not by Dr Franklin; Coales who is also a Grandson of F. Hopkinson’s thought that Franklin had unfairly attempted to take the credit of this Invention to himself. Coale and General Leakin urged me to stay some days at Baltimore, and expressed anxiety to manifest some token of public respect, which on many considerations I declined—
12. V. Friday— Baltimore to Philadelphia.

We took passage in the New Line to Philadelphia. Steam-boat Philadelphia, Captain Crocker— Peter C. Brooks junr and family, arrived at Barnum’s last Evening, after we were in bed; and we came away this morning before they were up. Mr Riston, Mr Ridgeley, Ex-Cadet Hughes, and Dr Denny, an assistant Surgeon in the Navy lately from the Mediterranean were among our fellow passengers. The number unusually small. The new line goes by the new Canal road— We landed from the Creek about noon and crossed in Stages to the City of Delaware, opposite to the Pea-patch or Fort Delaware. We stop’d at the Bridge of the deep cut 77 feet, which was shewn us by Mr Newbold. The landing on the Delaware side is 7 miles below Newcastle— We took the Steamboat Norfolk Captain, and arrived at 7. of the Evening at Philadelphia. We stop’d at Newcastle and took in the passengers of the Old Line, some accident having happened yesterday to one of their boats, so that she could not run this day. At Philadelphia we met P. R. Fendall at the wharf. We went to Head’s at the Mansion House, but there was no room there— We came to Renshaw’s United States Hotel and took lodgings for the Night— Met Edward Wyer in the Street. He arrived the Evening before the last from the Mediterranean, with despatches from Commodore Crane and Mr Offley at Smyrna— I sent for Mr J. Sergeant who came and spent an hour with me—desponding at the present situation of political affairs— Dr Harlan was one of our fellow-passengers in the boat from Newcastle.
13. IV— Saturday— Philadelphia to New-York

We took passage in the Union Line to New-York— At 6 this Morning we left the wharf in the Steam-boat Burlington, and after stopping at that place and at Bristol to land, and take in passengers, took the Stage at the Landing 7 Miles short of Trenton. I wrote to my wife before leaving Philadelphia— E. Wyer came on board the Boat, and took leave of me. He was going immediately in the boat for Baltimore, intending to reach Washington this Night. At 20 minutes past 8. we reached the landing, and passing through Trenton, Princeton, and Kingston arrived at New-Brunswick, at 1/2 past 12. distance 34 Miles— In passing through Trenton I had hoped to see Mr Southard, but was disappointed— The competition in the lines of Stages, hurries them through so that they stop’d scarcely five minutes to change their horses at Trenton. But as there were only 8 Stages waiting at the landing, and there were 104 passengers proceeding for New-York, the Boat after we left it came on to Bordentown, and thence came on in four more Stages to New-Brunswick— But we had to wait three quarters of an hour in the Steam boat Swan, which took us to New-York— There we landed at five in the afternoon. Genl. Wool was one of our fellow-passengers— In the Steam-boat Swan, I took up a Newspaper of New-York the Morning-Herald, and saw in it a paragraph, that the body of G. W. Adams had been found by Mr Ferris a Pilot, near Hurlgate. On landing at New-York, I met Mr Jerome of Boston, upon the wharf, who repeated the information, and said he had written to Genl Winthrop at Boston. We came to lodge at the City Hotel. George Sullivan, and Saml. L. Knapp called upon me— I went with Mr Sullivan to his House, and there saw Mr Asten, Sexton of Church, whom he had employed in the arrangements for the interment of the body. It was found, on Wednesday the 10th. at 3. in the afternoon by a boy named William Addison Waterbury having drifted with the tide on City-Island sixteen Miles from the City— A Coroner’s inquest was held on the body the same Evening, at the House of Mr Ferris a Pilot on the Island; and the next day the Coroner, with Dr Ten Broeck, a physician residing in the neighbourhood removed it to East-Chester, where it was deposited in the Tomb of Mr Drake—a Vestry man of the Episcopal Church at that place— Commodore Chauncey sent his boat to have the body brought to the Navy-Yard; but it was retained by the Coroner to be taken to East-Chester. I determined to go out there myself to-morrow, and Mr Sullivan agreed to go with me— He sent me a livery-stable man named Hartwell, of whom I engaged a Barouche to come for me at six to-morrow Morning and we are to breakfast with Mr Sullivan. I saw at his house Mrs Sullivan; their Son James and Mr Burns— I wrote to my wife the tidings of melancholy consolation.
14. IV:30— Sunday— To East-Chester— Funeral Service— Return to New-York.

At six this Morning, a Barouche with a driver named Hagar came for us to the City Hotel. With my Son John I went and breakfasted with Mr Sullivan 87. Chambers Street. And he then went with us to East-Chester sixteen Miles from the City on the Eastern Stage-road— We stopp’d first at the Stage-house. But the Episcopal Church is about half a mile further on, upon the right side of the road—near it, on the other side lives Dr Ten Broeck with whom we dined. The Minister Mr Carter performed the Morning service at another Church at New Rochelle, three miles distant. The Tomb opens from the road under the Church-yard. It was opened for me and John and I descended into the vault, and saw a plain neat mahogany Coffin wherein the remains of my beloved Son were deposited. I attempted to raise the lid, but it was fastened by two screws, and I had not the nerve to take them out. I propose to leave it here till the next Autumn, and then to have it removed to Quincy. At Dr Ten Broeck’s were delivered
to us the effects found upon the person— His watch with the hands stopp’d at 3:40 the time of the morning when he disappeared—with the chain and cypher-seal which I gave him— His pocket-book and papers—a loose shirt collar, silver pencil, comb, snuffbox, double pen knife, pair of gloves, a purse with about 2 dollars in change and the key of his trunk. No language can express my feelings on remarking the point of time at which the hour and minute hands of the watch had stop’d. Oh! where at that moment was the Soul of my Child?— The Sleeve-buttons were not those I had given him— The Clothing in which he was clad was left at the House of Mr Ferris on City Island where the Inquest was held by the Coroner Samuel Briggs. At Dr Ten Broeck’s we met his father who lives with him, Mr and Mrs. Nelson, his wife’s father and mother; three of her Sisters and one brother; children; and a Mr Cooper once a Captain in Coll. Smith’s regiment— John took a Copy of the Coroner’s Inquest. We attended at Church the Evening Service of Trinity Sunday read by the Revd. Mr Carter the Minister of the Church, who preached from 1. Timothy 4. Godliness is profitable for all things; having the promise of this life; and of that which is to come— Immediately after Church, Mr Carter performed the funeral service at the entrance of the Tomb, in presence of an assemblage of the Inhabitants of the vicinity— Among those present were two of my oldest friends, Peter Jay Munro and Herman Le Roy. Mr Munro invited me to take a bed at his house in the neighbourhood, but I declined. A Mr Haskell of Boston, who said I had formerly known him was also there, and expressed a deeply sympathising feeling with my misfortune. We returned to New-York, and I left Mr Sullivan at his house. Mr Isaac Bates, De Wint, Charles King, and Joseph Blunt called on me in course of the Evening.
15. V: Monday—

There was a heavy thunder-gust in the Night, and several showers this afternoon— The morning was very warm— There was a succession of visitors. John was out, accompanied by Mr De Wint, a great part of the day; in search of a Carriage and pair of Horses, which he finally found and purchased. About noon, I walked out and visited my niece Caroline De Wint at N. 31 Greenwich Street— She and her husband have been obliged to come to the City after having removed to Fishkill Landing, on Account of a Catarrhal Cough to which she is annually subject, and which they call the blossom Cold. It is much more severe in the Country than in the City. Her children are all at Fishkill Landing, and one of them has the fever and Ague. I visited also my old friend Daniel M’Cormick and found him in good health, though very feeble, being as he told me, in his 85th. year. He said he had been offered 40,000 dollars, for the House in Wall Street where he resides, but that a mere high price could not tempt him to remove at his time of life— I have known him residing there these forty years. The Street has in that time become the centre of all the commercial business of New-York, and the Banks and Insurance Offices have encroached on all the dwelling-houses down to Mr M’Cormick’s, the only one which remains as I first knew it. The population of the City has in the mean time increased at least seven fold— Joseph Pitcairn came in while I was there. He lives in the City with a man named
Sessovis, a German, to whom his daughter was married when they were last in Scotland He also came in while I was with Mr M’Cormick— I knew M’Cormick when he was not more than 45. and Pitcairn when under 30. M’Cormick must be at least 20 years older than Pitcairn; but they are now both in the sixth of Shakespear’s seven Ages— M’Cormick lingering in it from a life of prosperous celibacy, and regulated indulgence. Pitcairn hurried into it, by a life also of prosperous fortune, but of wild adventure and much vicissitude— He looks the most shattered of the two. Mr George Sullivan and Commodore Chauncey spent great part of the Evening with me— I thanked the Commodore again for his very obliging attentions in pursuing the discovery of the remains of my beloved and deplored Son George— He promised to concert with Mr Sullivan the necessary Arrangements for the removal of the body to Quincy, the next Autumn— I wrote this morning to my wife.
16. IV:30. Steam-boat Chancellor Livingston, from New-York— Tuesday—

I went this morning to Pelham Street N. 1. and found the house of my Correspondent from Delft, John Adams.— He was not at home, but I saw his daughter in Law; wife of his Son by his first marriage— She said he would be at home by twelve O’Clock, and I desired her to ask him to call upon me at the City Hotel before three. He came accordingly with his little boy to whom I gave a Bible— The daughter in Law told me that the boy’s mother had called him Christopher; and she believed had had him baptised by that name; but that the old man did not like it, and wanted to call the boy John— He was not baptised the day before yesterday at the reformed Dutch Church, as the old man wrote me he intended— Before I returned to the City Hotel from Pelham Street, ten O’Clock the hour at which Mr Sullivan was to call to go with me to visit Mr Oliver Wolcott had passed— Sullivan had called and left his Card; with his Son the Cadet. I rode with my Son John, and Mr De Wint, with the Chariotee and pair of horses that he had purchased, and visited Coll. Marinus Willett, now in his 90th. year— Full of vivacity and Conversation— Mr De Wint and Mr Joseph Blunt dined with us at the City Hotel, and Mr Sullivan came in while we were dining— Major Lamb, my old fellow passenger from England visited me before dinner, and told me that his wife died the last Autumn. Mr Benjamin Romaine also paid me a morning visit— Sullivan, De Wint and Blunt, accompanied us to the Steam-Packet Chancellor Livingston—Captain Coggeshall; in which we left the wharf precisely at four O’Clock— The Liverpool Packet Canada, to sail the first of next Month was on the other side of the wharf, and at the invitation of some of the proprietors I went on board of her and viewed her accommodations, which are very elegant— The Evening was fine, and the passage of the boat at the rate of at least twelve miles an hour— I conversed with Dr Miller of Princeton N.J. going with his Son Edward, upon a visit of one day to Boston— Also with Mr who told me he had married a daughter of Coll. T. H. Perkins—with Captain Northam of Newport, who told me that he was in the Benjamin Franklin, when my poor George was lost. A schoolmaster from Charleston S.C. named Parsons and professing to be a nephew of the late Chief Justice Theophilus, was also very talkative with me. My Sensations on passing by City-Island were agonizing— The whole Evening was passed in the gloom of the deepest dejection, and despondency, which it was impossible for me to shake off. Nature is impotent and helpless— The power of prayer alone is left— May I not be forsaken of my ever living, almighty benefactor, nor of my confidence in him.
17. IV:15— Wednesday.— Providence— Walpole— Fuller’s.

I was up just in time to see, from the Upper deck of the Steam-boat, the Sun rise; rejoicing in the East— We were then abreast of Block-Island; in sight of Point Judith: with smooth water, a clear atmosphere, and a cool light Eastern Breeze— We passed round Point Judith at 5. stop’d at Newport about 20 minutes to land, and take in passengers, and reached the wharf at Providence at 9. exactly seventeen hours from New-York. The distance is at least 200 miles. Several Stages were on the wharf, which took the passengers proceeding for Boston, where they must have arrived about three in the afternoon. I went to the Franklin Hotel; and there waited in the sitting Room till Noon. Meanwhile the Carriage and Horses were landed from the Boat, and the Horses had an interval of rest. Several of the Citizens of Providence called in while I was there. Among them were N. R. Knight the Senator, Mr Earle, Mr Tillinghast, Mr Parmenter, and Judge Pittman. They all spoke of great distress and ruin among the manufacturers. Heavy failures happening every day. Among the rest a house named Wilkinson, owners of the largest Cotton Establishment at Pawtucket; failed for half a Million of Dollars— Mr Knight told me that Governor Fenner’s Son in Law, named Millet, who had unsuccessfully gone lately to Washington, to obtain the Collector’s place, had failed, and involved Mr Fenner to the amount of thirty thousand dollars. The distress and want of money is almost universal— Immediately after noon we left Providence, and after stopping 20 minutes at Coll. Hatch’s at Attleborough, came at 20 minutes past four to Fuller’s Tavern at Walpole, where we put up for the Night— The heat of the weather was oppressive, and our horses being new and not used to each other were somewhat tried— I saw Coll. Hatch who was complaining of the Times, and fearful of losing his Office as Postmaster. We dined after arriving at Walpole, and having a long Evening before me, I employed it until dark in writing to my wife, and in my Diary— This while I have any use of my right hand, is a never failing resource for giving wings to Time; but I have neglected taking a book with me, and thereby lose some hours which should have been made profitable.
18. IV:15. Thursday. Walpole to Quincy— Home.

I rose with the Sun, and at a Quarter past six we left Fuller’s. Stop’d at the Post-Office five miles from his house, and left the Letter for my wife to be taken by the Mail from Boston to Washington. At a quarter past eight we came to Bride’s at Dedham, where we breakfasted, and at half past eleven alighted at my paternal Mansion in Quincy; which if it please God, is to be my home for the short remnant of my days— My brother and his family had left it in April— It was now uninhabited, and with scarcely any furniture in it. I determined however to take up my abode in it from this day. We went however to my brother’s House and dined. He had gone this morning to Boston, but came back to dinner. His family were all well, except Abigail who is suffering with a tooth-ache— My brother’s wife’s Mother is there; Mrs Harrod; and a young man named Gourgas, a lawyer in this town, came and dined with the family: he is engaged to my brother’s daughter Elizabeth— After dinner we returned to my own house, where I propose now to pass the Summer, and hope to make comfortable for my wife in Summers hereafter— There is now barely furniture enough in it to enable us to pass the night here, with the aid of Isaac Farrar who rents the farm, and of his wife. They live in the adjoining farm house. My Son Charles came out from Boston this afternoon, and returned in the Evening— Elizabeth C. Adams called in; and Louisa C. Smith, whom I invited to come and keep house for me this Summer which she promised to do. I wrote a Letter to my wife, informing her of our arrival. There was kitchen
and table-furniture in the house, with which we were enabled to have tea made in the Evening—and there is stabling for my horses, and room for my Chariotee in the barn. We made a short Evening, and retired early to bed. My situation here now strongly reminds me of that in which my father first came into the same House in June 1788— I enter it with a feeling of deep solemnity at the responsibilities devolving upon me, and at the prospects before me. Almighty God from whom alone all good thoughts, words and actions proceed, be present with me in thy Mercy. May I never be forsaken of thee, and never forget or disregard my entire dependence upon thee. Bestow upon me a Spirit of Gratitude, of Humility, of Cheerfulness and of Resignation— Of Gratitude, for the numberless blessings which thou hast given me to enjoy, and which thou art yet heaping upon me from hour to hour. Of Humility to be conscious of my own infirmities, and unworthiness— Of Cheerfulness to be contented with the favours thou art pleased to bestow; and of Resignation to the Dispensations of thy Will. Bless and preserve the partner of my life— The children thou hast given us: my kindred, friends, and Country; and finally all my fellow beings of the human race— Grant me Health, Peace of Mind, the Will and the Power to employ the remaining days which thou hast allotted me on Earth to purposes approved by thee and tributary to the well-being of others, and to my own preparation for appearing in thy presence to give an Account of the Deeds done in the Body. It is not in Man that walketh to direct his Steps. Be thou, Oh Merciful God, my Guide. Give me Discernment and Perseverance in Life, Fortitude in Death, and the hope and fruition of a blessed immortality.
19. IV:20— Friday.

I was up in the Night, unwell, and continued so all the morning of this day— Towards evening I was much better. What most affected me was the difficulty that I found in writing—greater than I ever experienced before. An evil for which I fear there is no remedy. I visited my Nursery of trees, raised from the seed; almost all of which are dead, killed by neglect and the severity of the last Winter— Louisa C. Smith came and passed the day with us, getting the house in order; which was done to a very considerable degree by my Son John and her with the aid of John Porter, Mrs Farrar, and Sally Hayden, a young girl whom John has engaged for housemaid. I looked on— Mr Whitney the Minister of the Parish, paid me an early morning visit. A Mr Allen of Bridgwater, called also to indulge his curiosity having as he said never seen my father, nor me before. My brother was here also this Morning. We breakfasted at 8. dined at 2 and took tea about 7. in the Evening. After dinner Mr Gardner Greene called: going with his family upon a Summer excursion to Sandwich. Genl Dearborn and Mr Degrand came together, and took tea with us. Degrand commenced immediately upon politics— Mr Calhoun, Mr Van Buren, and Mr Clay. Rail-roads and Canals— England, France and Colombia— Louis M’Lane, W. C. Rives and Tom P. Moore of Kentucky. Degrand is anxious to begin the Presidential campaign at once. My Son Charles came out from Boston, and returned there. He brought out a Deed from Joseph Curtis to Ward N. Boylston; of the Weston Farm— Deeds of Pews N. 1. 2 and 54. in the Stone Temple at Quincy. A Note from the Treasurer of the Congregational Society to the Executors of my father for 1400 dollars; and a note to me from Josiah Brigham Treasurer of the Quincy Canal Corporation for 280 dollars— All which he found among his brother George’s Papers. Also a Deed from Ebenezer and Josiah Adams to me of three quarters of an Acre, and 8 rods of land, which I had agreed to purchase of them; but this Deed is not recorded. Charles spoke to me also upon the subject concerning which Dr Storer had written me a Letter—
20. IV: Saturday.

We are continuing gradually our arrangements for housekeeping; but I am not getting into a proper course of occupation. Mr Marston called upon me this morning as he was going to Boston with his daughter, and another young Lady. Mr Thomas Greenleaf was here this forenoon. Mr Quincy now President of Harvard University was also here— He brought me a Letter from Horatio Greenough the Sculptor to him, written at Rome, and a Bill of Lading for my father’s Bust in Marble, which Greenough has executed for me, and which Mr Quincy has received, with one of himself. He mentioned that Greenough’s father was desirous of having the Busts opened and exhibited at the Athenaeum; to which I consented, as respected that of my father, on condition that the subsequent repacking of the Bust, and its delivery to me here at Quincy undamaged, shall be at Mr Greenough’s risk. Mr Quincy spoke to me also of the present condition of the University, and of its funds and accounts which have been loosely and carelessly kept— There has been some controversy on the subject, and the spunge has been passed on loose accountability because persons of fair and estimable characters have been involved in it— Mr Quincy said he was now merely observing and acquiring information, intending to wait till after commencement before he should begin to put in operation his purposes of improvement— He added that he should be glad to receive advice from any of his friends, and particularly from me. He expressed an earnest desire to promote the cultivation of the Greek and Latin Languages, which I approved; and I recommended that the Art of Book-keeping, or of Merchants Accounts should be introduced among the studies of the University— He said he would propose it to the Corporation— Coll. John Brazer Davis was here this afternoon, with my brother, and conversed much with me upon the Politics of the State I told him I would shortly communicate to him the manuscript of my Reply— My five Chests of Books and papers which have been deposited nearly three years in the vaults of the United States Branch Bank at Boston, were this day taken out by an order from me, and brought here. Louisa Smith passed the day with us, but returned to her lodgings this Evening. There was a heavy shower with thunder and Lightening at Night.
21. IV:25. Sunday.

I attended Meeting at the New Stone Meeting house, where Mr Young Minister of the New South Church at Boston, preached in the forenoon from Proverbs 22.2. “The rich and poor meet together: the Lord is the maker of them all,” and in the afternoon from 1. Corinthians 10.31. “Whether therefore ye eat, or drink, or whatsoever ye do, do all to the glory of God”— The preacher is the Son of Mr Young who was many years one of the Editors of the New-England Palladium, a newspaper published at Boston, and which commenced while I was practising Law there— The Son is now about thirty, and writes well, according to the present Cambridge Style of composition. The Meeting House is that which was proposed by my father’s donation to the town, and has been erected by the Parish— It is a spacious, neat, and elegant Building of the Granite or Sienite Stone, taken from the Quarry given by my father to the Town. It is generally in a Style of pure simplicity; but its external appearance is now greatly disfigured by a dark moisture which has oozed out from the Stones, staining unequally their surface, and giving to the whole an appearance of dirtiness. This does not happen generally to the Quincy
Stone, and it gives much concern to the people of the Parish, who still entertain however the hope that it is only an effusion from the interior of the Stone which will pass off in the course of two or three years. The House was dedicated on the 12th. of November 1828— The remains of my father and mother are deposited in the vault under the building which was granted to me by the Town and parish for the purpose— They were transported to it from the family tomb in the grave yard on the 1st. of April 1828. It is not easy to account to myself for the mingled emotions which I experienced at Meeting, upon this my first attendance on public worship at this house— My Soul was humbled to the dust; and my heart distressed almost to convulsion— The reading of the 284th. hymn had some effect in soothing my agitation. Abigail S. Adams and her brother Isaac Hull were here after Meeting this afternoon— I walked up to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, with William Greenleaf who overtook me on the way. On returning home I found Mr Daniel Greenleaf here. Mr George W. Beale had been here before; and Coll. and Mrs Quincy while I was out. Louisa C. Smith came and took up her abode with us.
22. V: Monday.

Ad poenitendum properat cito qui-judicat— I found this maxim this morning in an old pamphlet published in 1624. called a Plaine pathway to plantations; bound up with several others of the same date and among the rest with Edward Winslow’s Good Newes from New England— My Son John and Louisa Smith went into Boston this Morning, with the Chariotee and Horses, one of which has until this day been lame from a hurt on the left hind leg, probably taken on board the Steam-boat. I visited again my garden nursery, and examined more particularly the desolation of my young trees. In the Summer garden cellar, there are several remaining, perhaps one third of those which came up in the two preceding Summers. In the Nursery there are not one in ten living. The severity of the last winter killed most of them and weeds have strangled some of those which had survived the frost— I found several with the roots of weeds coiled round them like Serpents. The Horse-Chesnuts are almost all living, and next to them the Apricots have chiefly escaped. Three or four Oaks only out of hundreds remain; and of the Spanish Cork-oaks, not one—but I find the dead stalks and leaves of many of them— A few peaches and plums of the last year have come up. The garden is otherwise in no flourishing condition, and there is scarcely any fruit of any kind, upon the old trees. My brother was here in the forenoon. I dined alone, and in the afternoon walked out and called at Mr Whitney’s, at my brother’s, at Mr Marston’s and at Mr John Greenleaf’s. Mr and Mrs Whitney were gone this morning to Northborough— My brother and his family were at Mr John Greenleaf’s to take tea— On returning home I found that John and Louisa Smith had returned from Boston, and Charles was also here. John had brought me a Saddle and Bridle for mounting my horse. Charles brought me a Letter or note from me addressed to the judge of Probate of Suffolk County, declining to take out Administration of the Effects of my Son George, and requesting that Letters of Administration may be granted to Charles Francis Adams which I signed— He had also a probate Bond with the penalty of 8,000 dollars which we executed, myself and my Son John signing it as sureties, and Louisa C. Smith and Isaac Farrar as witnesses— Mr John Welles and Judge Joseph Hall
were here this afternoon while I was abroad. I received a Letter from my dear wife of the 16th. and one from Lieutenant T. B. Adams junr at Fort Moultrie Sullivan’s Island of the 9th.
23. IV:20. Tuesday.

My Son Charles went into Boston this Morning and returned again in the Evening. He took out this day the Letters of Administration upon the Estate of his brother George, and brought out two of his Account Books, and some of the papers shewing the state of his Accounts with me. I rode one of my Horses to Braintree a round of about nine miles; but I find him a very dangerous horse for me, and that if I ride him it will be at extreme peril. Immediately before dinner, I planted with John a number of large Chesnuts which E. Wyer sent me from the neighbourhood of Constantinople; but which not having been packed in sand will probably never come up. John planted also in the Garden some Lima Beans, which E. Wyer had been sent me from South-America by E. Wyer, in one of his former Voyages. The raising of trees from the seed, I find by three years experience to be so difficult and precarious that I shall abandon the attempt, except on the very small scale of my Nursery— The frost, the drought and the worm are three deadly enemies with whom it is in vain to contend, unless by a person always present and always vigilant. I had this Evening a long conversation with my Son Charles upon his prospects and purposes for his establishment, and for the future arrangement of my own affairs. He expects to be married on the first of September next to Abigail Brooks a daughter of Peter C. Brooks of Medford. I have always wished that one of my Sons at least should settle in this place of my nativity, and of that of my forefathers for nearly two centuries. I had hopes that this would have been done by George— Those hopes by the will of Heaven have been extinguished—upon which my duty is humble and submissive resignation. John has no inclination to come here, and the circumstances of his family make it probable that his Settlement will be at Washington— I have transferred to Charles the Agency of my Affairs in Boston, and intend to charge him with my concerns here. My first object is to place my property in such a state that I may live with my family without encroaching upon my capital. The next is to build a house here, in which my Library my own manuscript books and papers, and those of my father may be deposited for preservation: but for the execution of these designs there must be much further exertion, meditation, perseverance, and above all a blessing.
24. IV. Wednesday St. John’s day— Summer Solstice ends.

I marked the place of the Sun’s rising, at the extreme of his Northern Declination. Looking from the Southern door and Eastern window of my bed chamber he rose behind the centre of a tree bordering on the lane that leads to Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s House— Charles went to Boston this Morning, and to Medford this Evening. John went to Boston after dinner; and returned in the Evening; to make some dispositions for a purchase of furniture. I rode my second horse round by the railway before dinner; but find him as unsuitable for a saddle horse as the other. Mr Eliphalet Loud, and Mr Terrell of Weymouth called upon me concerning the money paid by the Russian Government, as indemnity for the capture of the Ship Commerce belonging to the Weymouth importing Company— This money was paid
nearly 18 months since but has not yet been received by the Company. There has been much negligence and some blundering at the department of State concerning it, and the Company are under great concern that they shall after all lose the money. I promised to write for them immediately to the Secretary of State— Mr Fiske the owner of a lumber-yard at the head of the Canal called upon me to enquire if I should want Lumber, he having heard that I proposed repairing my house— I informed him that I should probably not undertake that operation this Summer— Judge Story and Mr Coleman of Salem paid me a morning visit. After dinner Mr Dillingham brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr Charles Miner of West-Chester Pennsylvania, a member of the last and preceding Congress. Mr Dillingham is himself a Lawyer, residing at Chester, but a native of the County of Berkshire in this Commonwealth— Mr John Bailey called while he was here. I gave Mr Bailey the manuscript of my reply to read, and to give me his opinions upon it, which he promised— Mr Bacheler came to invite my subscription to an anti-universalist Newspaper, which I declined, informing him that I wished to have no concern with any religious controversy: for that I believed Christians of all denominations were only travelling by different roads to the same end— He then told me that he proposed to publish an antimasonic paper at Patucket, and asked my opinion upon that question. I told him that until lately I had thought not unfavourably of the masonic institution; nor yet very favourably—but that having now become a subject of party dissension, I thought it mischievous and hoped it would be voluntarily given up: but that I was not disposed to countenance any persecution against it or against any of its members— I declined patronizing his proposed paper. Mr Joseph Russell and Coll. Quincy called in the Evening— Mr and Mrs Russell are upon a visit to Mr Quincy, who is residing at his father’s house in this Town. He spoke to me of my father’s Bust, and of Mr Greenough’s wish that it may be exhibited at the Athenaeum, and I repeated to him what I had said last week to his father. I called this Evening at Mr George W. Beale’s, but he was not at home—
25. IV. Thursday.— Ride to Jamaica Plains.

After breakfast this morning I walked with my Son John to the hill opposite to the house, with the view of examining a site for erecting a house, which I propose to build if I can provide the necessary means. My intention is to adapt the erection of this house to the accomplishment of the second purpose of my father in his donations to this Town; the building of a Stone School-House for an Academy. The spot where I wish to build is in the rear of the lot of 8 Acres of land near the New Meeting House, given by my father to the Town. The situation is one of the most beautiful in the world, and the objects as connected together are of great interest to the public, as well as to my family.— But my designs are yet fluctuating in my mind, and I dare scarcely flatter myself that I shall have life and means to carry them into effect— I will not however prematurely despair—and I wish to proceed with due deliberation. Lieutenant Governor Winthrop paid me a Morning visit— I wrote to Martin Van Buren Secretary of State in behalf of the Weymouth importing company— Immediately after dinner I rode to Jamaica Plains, and called upon Mr Nathaniel Curtis, and afterwards upon Mrs Boylston my Co-executor and Executrix of the Will of Ward Nicholas Boylston— Mr Curtis exhibited to me a Statement of his proceedings in Execution of the Will, which appear to have been prudent and proper, and he advised with me concerning the further steps to be taken for the disposal of the property— There is land in various places to be sold— I agreed to meet Mr Curtis at Judge Robbins’s probate Court at Dedham on Wednesday the 8th. of next Month at 4 O’Clock in the afternoon. I
promised to see Mr Francis Treasurer of Harvard University and Isaac P. Davis concerning Mr Boylston’s bequests to that Institution— Mr Petty Vaughan is employed as agent for the Settlement of the Estate in England— In a Late Letter he intimates that Releases of certain claims under T. Boylston’s Will may be necessary and among the rest one from me—but I do not so suppose— Mrs Boylston put into my hands a small file of papers relating to the Settlement of Mr W. N. Boylston, with the Town of Boston, upon a donation to them by Thomas Boylston. On my return to Quincy I found my Son Charles who had come out from Boston.
26. IV. Friday.

Charles went to Boston this morning and returned this Evening. He sent out some household furniture which he purchased at Auction yesterday. Visitors from Boston and Hingham, morning and afternoon, and Mr George W. Beale in the Evening with Miss Whiting and his daughter— Mr Wirt has been some time in Boston, to argue a Cause in Chancery before the Supreme Court of the State, in which the Administrators of Tuthill Hubbard sue Peter C. Brooks, to re open an Account settled more than twenty years since; and to recover of him, from one to two hundred thousand dollars. The cause has been eight or ten days on trial, and the Argument was closed by Mr Wirt, but yesterday. Mr Smith who came with Mr Brooks of Hingham, is the teacher of the Academy there— I went this forenoon with my Son John to the foot of Penn’s Hill to enquire into the state of my farm at that place— I found Harvey Field Tenant of the House in which I was born, together with his nephew William Field, who is recently married. The adjoining House in which my father was born, is occupied by two Sons of Noah Curtis, who are Shoemakers— One of them is now building a house in the neighbourhood, and the other wishes to do the same upon a spot of land belonging to me and adjoining the House where they live— His father wrote to me last winter to enquire if I would sell about half an Acre of my land there, and I postponed a determination upon the proposal till I should come here— In the mean time the Land was appraised at the rate of 600 dollars an Acre which is too low. I told Curtis he should have half an Acre 8 rods front for 400 dollars— He said he would think of it. The two brothers were at work, and had five journeymen at work in the shop with them— I had some talk with them, and also with Harvey Field, upon the state of business and property in the town— The Curtis’s and Harvey Field are industrious and intelligent men. Field is a butcher, and finds other occasional occupations— He said he had been for two Months past keeping three or four fishing boats out, supplying the town with fish: but that the Season for that was now over— As we were walking towards the valley at the foot of Penn’s Hill, we saw on the Old Mill-Pond Hill, men at work erecting a new Stone School-House— G. W. Beale told me this Evening that he had determined to build at Squantum. I have taken in my leisure to reading the Letters of Madame du Deffand to Horace Walpole, which seem to open a strange page in the volume of human nature.
27. IV. Saturday.

Morning visits from Mr Codman the Minister of Dorchester and Mr Worthy also a Minister from Washington Pennsylvania, who has been attending a Convention at the theological Institution at Andover— He spoke of the

Politics of the State of Pennsylvania, and particularly of Mr Lawrence the member of the House of Representatives in the last Congress from that District. He spoke as a friend of the last Administration, and said that in that District the line between those dispositions and the opposite was the line between intelligence and ignorance, and between virtue and vice— Mr Agar was a visitor from curiosity; a Shoemaker belonging to Weymouth; who said he called because he was going to Boston; and did not like to pass by without seeing me— He told me that there were more shoes made in Weymouth, than in Braintree and Quincy together— Coll. Quincy and Mr Greenwood came together; and Mrs Gerry with her Son, still the Surveyor of the Port of Boston. John and Charles went to Boston this morning, and returned late this Evening, having visited Mrs. Everett this afternoon at Winter Hill— The weather which since my return here has been almost cold was this morning warm; and I bathed at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf—but the water was so cold that I merely swam into the middle of the Creek and returned. Towards Evening I paid a visit to Mr Daniel Greenleaf, and found him in the room which they call father Flynt’s Study— The House was built by the second Edmund Quincy, father of Daniel Quincy by Joanna Hoare his first wife, and of the third Edmund Quincy, the judge and Province Agent, by Elizabeth Gookin his second wife. I have not yet come to a regular course of occupation but am approaching to it— Reading this morning the 18th. Chapter of the Book of Exodus, it struck me there was in the advice of Jethro to Moses the first discrimination between the Legislative and Executive Powers of Government. but more between either of them and the judicial.— The Legislator was God— Moses received, recorded, and proclaimed the Laws. Moses was at first the sole judge; but at the advice of Jethro his father in Law, appointed Rulers of thousands of hundreds of fifties and of tens, to decide all small causes, and reserving to himself the decision, of the hard and great ones— I continue reading the Letters of Madame du Deffand, which are interesting I scarcely know why.
28. IV:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Charles Lowell of Boston, from Matthew 6.28. [“]And why take ye thought for raiment? Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow; they toil not, neither do they spin: 29. And yet I say unto you, that even Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these”— The discourse was very short. The absolute unqualified character of this precept was noticed, and considered as applicable only to the disciples of the time of Christ himself. It was perhaps also specially addressed to the peculiar character of the Nation; at all times noted for greediness of gain— The moral doctrines of Christianity are generally founded upon an exclusion of selfishness— Love, Reverence, and submission to God is the first of Christian duties and virtues— To love his neighbour as himself is the second— The general precept therefore allows him to love himself as his neighbour, but as by the Law of Nature man loves himself more than his neighbour, to counteract this propensity the special precepts of Christ often seem to require of him to love his neighbour more than himself— Thus while his injunctions are so positive and so repeated against taking thought for the morrow, and against solicitude for the necessaries of life, the parable of the ten virgins, and of the talents and the frequent references to faithful stewardship, are equally strong and pointed in favour of Industry and frugality— In this passage of the 6th. chapter of Matthew from the 19th. to the 34th. verse, the doctrine is not against Industry,
but against avarice, against the accumulation of, against extreme solicitude for future wants— The allusion to the lilies of the field and to Solomon, is by way of illustration, beautiful in thought, striking to the imagination—presenting in pregnant contrast the profusion of ornament in the bounties of nature, with the utmost magnificence of human toil— But the precept itself is not in this similitude. Christ does not mean to tell his disciples that they should not toil and spin; but that they should not consume themselves with cares to hoard up treasures. Mr Lowell’s afternoon Sermon was from 1. John 2.13. part of the verse— “I write unto you, fathers— I write unto you, young men.” Also very short— Mr Lowell is labouring under ill health— His manner is very solemn; his voice strong and harmonious, but his elocution slow to a degree that loses all animation. The day was cold and showery. Returning from Meeting this afternoon, I found Mr George Sullivan, and his Son, the late Cadet here— They left New-York yesterday: left the Stage at Dedham to come round this way in a Gig; went hence into Boston, and start again to-morrow for New-York. My brother with his two daughters, Susan Harrod and Mr Gourgas were here, on their way to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s— I executed a power to my brother to vote for me to-morrow at the annual meeting of the proprietors of the Braintree and Weymouth Turnpike for the choice of Directors.
29. IV:30. Monday.

I executed this morning two Powers of Attorney, one to receive dividends at the New-England Insurance Company, and the other at the Fire and Marine Insurance Company in Boston— We went in this morning, and came out again at Night— The Revd. Mr Foot is a Presbyterian Clergyman from Hampshire County who called upon me from curiosity, and with whom I conversed upon various subjects, chiefly political— He spoke as a warm friend of the American system of internal improvement and encouragement of manufactures. Other visitors occupied great part of the morning and afternoon. Mr Brooks and his eldest son came before dinner. They walked with me to the top of the hill where I propose to build a House— Mr Brooks approved very much of the site, and advised me to begin by planting a number of trees. He spoke with much satisfaction of the termination of the argument in the cause recently tried before the Supreme Court of the State in which he was a party, and of the Deportment of Mr Wirt, employed as Counsel against him. The Chancery Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of the State has been lately much enlarged; but this trial has not been a happy exemplification of its usefulness.— Mr Edward Miller is one of my Quincy neighbours, and called to pay a morning visit— He is recovering from indisposition— Mr and Mrs Foster, and Mr Davis with Mr Shepherd were here after dinner. Mr Shepherd’s daughter was some Months since married to Mr Gorham Brooks, and they are gone to Europe— Davis spoke to me of a half-pipe of Madeira Wine, that he has received for me from Mr March at New-York; and also of the unfinished portrait of me, commenced in 1826 by Stewart, for Mr Boylston, and which he bequeathed to Harvard University— It has been proposed to Mr Sully of Philadelphia to finish it; to which he has consented, and Mr Davis promises to write to him, to come as soon as he can to Boston for that purpose. The day was
showery, and confined me, great part of it to the House— But towards Evening I rode with John round by the farms and the cross road to the brook, returning by the Railway-House, and the Stone Meeting House there building— Our Cook came out this afternoon from Boston, where Charles engaged her— Mr Foster had been attending the Meeting of the Directors of the Braintree and Weymouth Turnpike, of which he is Treasurer, and of which my brother is President.
30. IV:20. Tuesday.

I went up this Morning to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, and he took the acknowledgment of a power which I executed to my Son Charles to receive dividends upon any United States 6 per cent Stocks standing in my name, and which he took with him to Boston— I spoke also to Mr Greenleaf of my wish that preparations should be made for carrying into execution the second object of my father’s donations to the town of Quincy. the erection of a Stone School House over the cellar of the House in which Governor Hancock was born— I told him of my design to build a House on the brow of the Hill behind the Square given by my father to the Town, and that my means of effecting this purpose would depend upon the opening of the Square— I said I was not desirous of urging the erection of the School-house prematurely; but that the plan of it, and the estimate of the cost of building it, and also of the foundation necessary for supporting a teacher of the School should be made— I said it was not my purpose that it should cost any thing to the Town, but my intention was to contribute something to the accomplishment of the object myself, if I should possess the means— Mr Greenleaf said he would call upon me, and take measures for having the estimates and the plans prepared— He proposed also to go with me to the Meeting-House, to view the side of the Wall to which the Tablet with the obituary Inscription, and the Bust of my father is to be adapted— I told him I should make enquiries whether the Tablet could be made of polished Granite— Mr Gray the Minister at Jamaica Plains and Mr George Whitney paid me a morning visit, and William Greenleaf in the afternoon. The day was cold and showery. I attempted to commence the breaking up of the ground in my Nursery with the spade and hoe, but was driven back to the House by the rain— Towards Evening I walked to my brother’s and spent half an hour with him and his family. I read a few Letters of Madame du Deffand; part of the Article in Buffon’s Natural History upon the Cock—part of the Article in the Dictionaire Oeconomique of Chomel, edited by La Marre, upon the Treatment of fowls, and some papers of my father’s, the assortment of which I propose to make— I also made out a list of the Lots of Land which I propose to have surveyed. Charles says I have too many irons in the fire—

Day. The first ten days of the Month were occupied at Washington, as those which had preceded. I was a week travelling from Washington to Quincy, and have been here since the 18th. I rise between 4. and 4:27. read two Chapters in the Bible—write in my diary till 7 or 8 when we breakfast— Read, write, receive visitors, and visit the garden till 2 when we dine. Sleep an hour after dinner, and have no settled occupation for the remainder of the day. Bed from 10 to 11—
